name: University of Colorado Boulder (CU Science Discovery)
description:
CU Science Discovery is a science education outreach program of the University of Colorado Boulder’s Division of Continuing Education. Founded in 1983 to heighten young students’ interest in science, CU Science Discovery coordinates an array of programs that connect K-12 students and teachers to current CU science. Each program utilizes CU scientific expertise, equipment, resources and graduate or undergraduate students in order to provide K-12 students and teachers with unique, experiential learning STEM experiences. All programs are designed to be highly interactive and relevant, in order to engage students in the scientific process while connecting them to the science and technology present in their everyday lives.

We provide STEM programming during the school year (through in-school presentations and workshops, as well as after-school and day-off programming on the CU Boulder campus) as well as throughout the summer (we have a large summer camp program based on the CU Boulder campus, with some additional programs happening on the CU Anschutz medical campus). We partner with schools and school districts (eg, BVSD, Adams 12), public libraries, community organizations (eg, Nature Kids, E-Movement) and CU Boulder faculty, who frequently incorporate our programs as part of their Broader Impacts activities for federal grants. 

Through hands-on summer camps and after-school classes, homeschool classes, teacher workshops, school programs, and community outreach events, Science Discovery impacts approximately 30,000 students, teachers and community members throughout Colorado each year.

name: eduKatey, LLC
description:
1. Engineering for us all (e4usa) teacher professional learning. Partner teachers in public, private, and charter high schools across the nation, university partners, and industry partners are in support of all of them.

2. Global STEM Challenges Program in Fairfax County Public Schools, VA. I support teachers grades 9-11 to teach integrated math, integrated science, and integrated engineering PBL-based courses centered on the NAE Grand Challenges of Engineering. The National Academy of Engineering is a partner of the District for this program as is the Knowles Teacher Initiative.

3. The IceCube Neutrino Telescope high school student internship and teacher materials design and support. IceCube is a telescope at the South Pole, the NSF PI is at University of Wisconsin-Madison. I teach high school students in WI, MN, and SD about IceCube, coding in Python, and engineering design in an annual virtual internship. I also teach MN high schoolers in a summer Upward Bound camp focused on IceCube-related STEM with a teacher-training component, and I develop instructional materials for IceCube for national distribution.

4. With Purdue, sponsored by KEEN and ASU, I am co-leading a course for engineering professors across the USA on using bio-inspired design and STEAM for increased entrepreneurial mindsets in undergrad engineering majors. Three years of funding for six semester-long courses.

5. With the Knowles Teacher Initiative and Knowles Engineering Senior Fellows, I am the co-leading a course for high school math and science teachers across the nation to use social justice issues as vectors for learning about engineering design and developing math and science mastery. 

6+. I do a smattering of teacher PD and student workshops that are not within the contexts of the long-duration partnerships listed above.

name: The Henry Ford
description:
Invention Convention Worldwide is a global K-12 invention education program that teaches students problem-identification, problem-solving, entrepreneurship and creativity skills and builds confidence in invention, innovation and entrepreneurship for life. Invention Convention programs happen at the school, local, regional and national levels in the United States and a growing number of countries worldwide. Our curriculum is free, flexible and can be used in classrooms, afterschool programs or independent study. 

The Invention Convention Curriculum uses a framework that follows the seven steps of the invention process. It includes introductory lessons to help students get started. It also introduces students to entrepreneurial concepts to get them thinking about what happens beyond the invention process.

The seven-step invention process lives at the heart of the Invention Convention curriculum. Students complete step-by-step lessons to develop an invention that is original and well-constructed and that solves a real-world problem.

https://inhub.thehenryford.org/curriculum-resources/invention-convention-curriculum

name: Colorado Department of Education
description:
As a dynamic service agency, the Colorado Department of Education (CDE) provides leadership, resources, support and accountability to the state’s 178 school districts, 1,888 schools, over 53,000 teachers and over 3,200 administrators to help them build capacity to meet the needs of the state’s approximately 905,000 public school students.

CDE also provides services and support to boards of cooperative educational services (BOCES), early learning centers, state correctional schools, facility schools, the state’s libraries, adult/family literacy centers, and General Education Development (GED) testing centers reaching learners of all ages. CDE operates the Colorado Talking Book Library which provides supports for people who have vision, print, and reading disabilities.In addition, CDE provides structural and administrative support to the Colorado School for the Deaf and the Blind and the Charter School Institute.

CDE serves students, parents, and the general public by protecting the public trust through ensuring adherence to laws, strong stewardship of public funds, and accountability for student performance. 

As the administrative arm of the State Board of Education, CDE is responsible for implementing state and federal education laws, disbursing state and federal funds, holding schools and districts accountable for performance, licensing all educators, and providing public transparency of performance and financial data. CDE is led by the Commissioner of Education, a position that is appointed by the State Board of Education.

name: eBodyGuard
description:
eBodyGuard has created 4 innovations, with three of them launching in the next week, by November 15th, 2022.  The focus of the eBodyGuard technology, accessible at the App and Google Play store, for the community is to provide the ability for each and every person to have their needs met in their most vulnerable moments as they embrace 911; whether this is a medical need, safety need, a need for their family, and a need that involves their vehicle or pet within their location so First Responders can respond within a timely manner and support them specifically.  The voice activation of the technology provides access to activating this so that if 911 needs to be reached without touching their phone, this is also possible.  

The eBodyGuard eBodyCam is a new technology that finally gives video recording to the community in a fashion that is true objective evidence.  It works during the 911 call and without the 911 call.  Providing the community two minutes of high resolution recording; the moment the video has been taken; eBodyGuard protects the video and holds this for the community in the eBodyGuardcommunity.com where the Community/User can view their video.  If a crime occurs, and if 911 was utilized, this video is sent on to Law Enforcement to ensure the court process is supported.  Since eBodyGuard is an FBI CJIS secure company and follows all federal and state and local laws, the privacy of the data is strictly adhered to and also supports the needed bridging of this delicate gap between the individual's need and the government usage of the data:  only in case of a crime, will the data/video be provided. 

The eBodyGuardCommunity.Com portal is also going live in mid-November along with the www.eBodyGuardPublicSafety.com portal.  These portals are going to mirror one another in that the User's Safety Card, eBodyCam, and any additional data and documents that are uploaded for the 911 call will be provided for view access only to the user.  They can enter the website through their passcode created on their App.  The community will view what data was provided to 911 and likewise what law enforcement now has.   

We believe Safety is primal and everyone deserves to know safety. Our base service is ALWAYS free and will remain free to everyone.  The additional eBodyCam coming to market will be a nominal optional in-App purchase to cover the cost of storage. 

eBodyGuard, our mission:  We are the Bridge
Our vision:  through technology, people, and processes because connections create safety.

name: KMLabs
description: The primary focus of KMLabs is to design and manufacture tabletop scale laser sources that span the vacuum ultraviolet (VUV) to extreme ultraviolet (EUV) to soft X-ray (SXR) range of the electromagnetic spectrum—about 1 to 150 nm.  Because laser technology has generally been limited to wavelengths only as short as 193 nm, scientific research in the VUV to SXR range has been relatively less explored. With recent developments in high harmonic generation (HHG), research in this area is coming of age and opening up exciting new opportunities for scientific discovery. Specifically, the potential for nanoscale imaging, spectroscopy, and probing ultrafast dynamics are extending the domain of nano and quantum experimentation beyond the specialized expertise of the laser physics lab and into the broader hands of materials scientists, engineers, geologists, and more.

Through our efforts, we hope to encourage fair wages and workplaces, social equity, affordable education and health care, and the increased use of clean energy. The BEST Program:
-BEST drives middle and high school students' higher education and career choices and develops their workforce skills and readiness.
-The free program is executed via a fun, exciting fall robotics competition and supported by spring and summer online opportunities.
-Our student-led teams improve their STEM and life skills while working within an 8-week schedule to design, develop and construct robots with free program-provided materials, training, and events

description: The Climate Literacy and Energy Awareness Network (CLEAN) is a nationally renowned, award-winning, free online clearinghouse that features; i) 700+ high-quality resources around climate and energy topics that are peer-reviewed for scientific accuracy, ii) pedagogic effectiveness and classroom readiness guidance for educators (“Toolkit”) and iii) is home to the vibrant CLEAN Network. The CLEAN Collection is syndicated to NOAA’s Teaching Climate portal. CLEANet.org and Climate.gov are the premier resource portals for climate education resources in the country with over 55,000 combined monthly sessions.

name: Data Puzzles
description:
Are you looking for ways to bring authentic and relevant scientific data into your classroom? You've come to the right place! Data Puzzles combine classroom-friendly scientific datasets with the research-backed pedagogical practices of Ambitious Science Teaching to give your students the ultimate inquiry-based learning experience.

We believe that students should learn science the same way scientists do - through exploration, discovery, and sense-making grounded in observations of the natural world. In a way, science is like a puzzle - the bigger picture is revealed after hunting for and putting the pieces together. Our planet is full of exciting and intriguing phenomena - invite them into your science classroom today!

name: GeoMag
description: Explore the power of community/citizen science, Earth's magnetic field, space weather, and data collection with a series of lessons, videos, and webinars designed for middle and high school students, undergraduate students and the general public. Your data contributions will help scientists understand changes in Earth's magnetic field that will lead to improvements in navigation and help to protect our communication systems and electric grid from space weather.

name: QGreenland
description:
A free mapping tool to support interdisciplinary Greenland-focused research, teaching, decision making, and collaboration.

Combines key datasets into a unified, all-in-one GIS analysis and visualization environment for offline and online use.

An international Editorial Board and Project Collaborators connects the QGreenland Team to data and user communities.

name: Girls* on Rock
description: Girls* on Rock is a unique, FREE, wilderness science education program for high school girls*. Each summer a team of 8-9 participants and 3 instructors spend 12 days exploring and learning about the alpine landscapes of the Rocky Mountains through art, rock climbing, and conducting scientific field studies with our team of professional glaciologists, ecologists, mountain guides, and artists.

name: HEART Force (Hazard Education, Awareness, and Resilience Task Force )
description:
Environmental hazards—such as wildfire, flood, and drought—are increasingly affecting communities in Colorado. With this rise in hazardous events, there is a pressing need for communities to become more resilient through education, preparation, and planning.

The Hazard Education, Awareness, and Resilience Task Force (HEART Force) is a collaborative project implemented by the NOAA Cooperative Institute for Research in Environmental Sciences (CIRES) and NOAA’s Regional Integrated Sciences and Assessments (RISA) partner Western Water Assessment.

name: Fiske Drifting North Polar Planetarium Field Trip
description:
In this Middle School/High School unit, students will be transported to the Arctic with the MOSAiC expedition, The Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Arctic Climate, in an immersive classroom and field trip experience. 

The Drifting North Polar Planetarium Experience invites students to explore what it was like to participate in the MOSAiC expedition to the North Pole. The unit includes five lessons, five activities, and a 30-minute film. 

MOSAiC was an unprecedented international research expedition to study the physical, chemical, and biological processes that couple the Arctic atmosphere, sea ice, ocean, and ecosystem. The German icebreaker Polarstern began MOSAiC’s journey in Tromsö, Norway, sailing north of the Northern Lights and parking against a block of sea ice. The Polarstern drifted with the ice for 13 months, much like the ship of Norwegian explorer Fridtjof Nansen 125 years ago. More than two dozen scientists, engineers, educators, and others from the University of Colorado Boulder and NOAA joined scientists from 16 other nations for the international MOSAiC mission: the Multidisciplinary Drifting Observatory for the Study of Arctic Climate

Visit your local planetarium for a field trip for the full dome experience or facilitate the unit in your classroom using the free 2D film and lesson materials.

name: MOSAiC Classroom Curriculum
description:
The Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Study of Arctic Climate (MOSAiC) is an international expedition to the Arctic. Engage with the science of MOSAiC through education and outreach activities.

Bring MOSAiC into your classroom with Data Puzzles, 360-degree virtual experiences, the Polar Planetarium field trip, classroom curriculum, and more learning resources. Experience MOSAiC all around you with two planetarium films featuring footage captured by videographers on the Polarstern now showing at Fiske Planetarium in Boulder (also available to view in 2D).

name: Right Here, Right Now Global Climate Summit
description:
The Right Here Right Now Global Climate Summit (RHRN) focuses on the human rights impacts and challenges created by climate change as well as the need for human-focused solutions. For further background on the conference and a human rights-centered perspective, please review this article: “How a human rights approach to climate change can spark real change.” 

The RHRN Educator’s Guide strives to support educators working to connect formal and informal learning spaces to the conference content. The guide is divided into three sections to match the three conference themes: Impacts, Obligations, and Solutions, and includes educational materials focused on climate science and understanding earth systems through a human rights lens.  

The Educator’s guide complements the conference resources developed for each theme: 

Impacts: Understanding the Vulnerabilities of Climate Change 

Obligations: Who Is Responsible? 

Solutions: Human Rights-Based Climate Solutions

name: Science Show & Share Webinar Series
description:
The CIRES Science Show & Share webinar series connects middle and high school students with scientists from around the world. Join us for a 40-minute virtual session. The scientists will share about their work, what they are doing, how they are doing it, and why it's important for about 20 minutes, followed by a live Q&A session. 

We will feature topics on current environmental events like Earth Day and COP26, as well as, connect with researchers from some of the most remote locations in the world.

The webinar recordings can be used as stand-alone classroom resources. This program is a continuation of the successful Science@Home program.

name: Polar Science Early Career Community Office (PSECCO)

Our mission is to empower and elevate early career scientists in the polar sciences, support a vibrant community, provide opportunities and resources, offer skill trainings and work together towards a more just, inclusive, diverse, equitable and accessible polar science environment.

name: Emily Griffith Technical College
description:
EGTC offers nearly 50 workforce training programs including 28 Career and Technical (CTE) certificate programs; 11 registered apprenticeship programs at 16 sites throughout Colorado; courses in English Language Acquisition (ELA) and High School Equivalency (HSE); and Vocational Transitions courses that create pathways for underserved populations to move into the College’s certificate programs. A primary focus of EGTC is to meet students where they are and to serve them according to their needs, and does so by offering evening and weekend class hours, programs of varying lengths with multiple start dates throughout the year, and robust student support services.

Each year, EGTC serves nearly 8,000 students in all of its programs including apprenticeships. Students’ ages range from 16-65 or older, with the average being 29. Sixty-seven percent of EGTC’s student population is considered low-to-moderate income according to federal poverty guidelines. Career training programs such as those offered at EGTC give students valuable skills and credentials for Colorado’s top jobs, while also providing key industries with pipelines of skilled workers.

name: OERColorado
description:
The OERColorado Project is a statewide initiative to provide digital collections of free openly-licensed curriculum resources for Colorado educators to use in their teaching and classrooms. OERColorado.org is administered by the Colorado River Board of Cooperative Education Services (CR BOCES) and Colorado Empowered Learning (CEL) (C.R.S. § 22-5-119). The mission of OERColorado is to support Colorado educators, administrators, and other educational stakeholders in PK-12+ in using Open Educational Resources (OER) materials, share ideas, and create affordable, high quality learning resources.
OER stands for Open Educational Resources. The resources in the OERColorado public digital libraries include free lessons, classes, textbooks, simulations, games, rubrics, icebreakers, and many other educational tools for teachers to use in face-to-face, online and blended learning environments. We make finding openly licensed resources easier by creating a one-stop location to: +Adopt, use, or customize an open access textbook, +Address learning loss and increase engagement, +Find evidence-based resources, +Supplement existing curriculum, +Locate niche curriculum like primary sources, historical information, Colorado focused career & technical education, +Adapt lessons to individual student needs to improve accessibility, +Find bilingual/bicultural materials, primary sources, Colorado-based examples and more, +Collaborate with others on shared curriculum, events and initiatives using built in groups and tools, +Create and share OER resources and materials

name: The Denver STEAM Foundation
description:
In January 2024, the Denver STEAM Foundation (DSF) was born from a collective vision to address the lack of holistic STEAM educational opportunities for Black scholars across the Denver-Metro region. Our mission emerged from a deep commitment to rewrite the narrative for Black K-12 learners, recognizing the systemic barriers they face in accessing a quality education. 

DSF is a beacon for change, dedicated to tailoring initiatives that celebrate and build upon the rich history and brilliance of our community. We understand that true empowerment extends beyond the classroom, encompassing families, communities, and the world at large. Our programs are designed to uplift scholars holistically, recognizing the interconnectedness of their personal and academic journeys. 

At the heart of our mission lies the cultivation of future leaders and changemakers. We envision a STEAM landscape that mirrors the diversity and identities of its participants– a space where every voice is heard, valued, and empowered to innovate. 

Through DSF, we embark on a transformative journey, championing equity, inclusivity, and excellence in STEAM education. Together, we pave the way for a brighter, more equitable future–one where every scholar has the opportunity to thrive and redefine what’s possible in the world of STEAM.

name: Visuospatial Education Center (VEC EDU)
description: There is a need in education for a visuospatial assessment of the affective symmetry gauging (ASG) ability revealed via the magnocellular visual pathway (Tootell et al, 2021). The combined visual, emotional and spatial abilities contribute in the physiological processes of ideation (Damasio, 201; Ferg, 2011, 2018; Masland, 2020). Ideation (the development of original thought) involves the ASG and engaging spatial sequential memory, which is used for cognitive methods of logical and comparative reasoning. A sense of order is required for both the rational (logical and comparative) thought and the unconditional emotional response of pleasingness for the sensorimotor spatial frequency associations (Damasio, 2018). name: Colorado Workforce Development Council (CWDC)
description:
The Colorado Workforce Development Council (CWDC) is a Governor-appointed, public-private partnership with the purpose to advise, oversee, and integrate the work of the Colorado talent development network. The CWDC Office is the work unit that supports the Council.

Our vision is that every Colorado employer has access to a skilled workforce and every Coloradan has the opportunity for meaningful employment, resulting in individual and statewide economic prosperity. The CWDC’s mission is to enhance and sustain a skills-based talent development network that meets the needs of employers, workers, job seekers, and learners for today and tomorrow. The CWDC's values are equity, agility, and integration.

name: CIRES Center for Education, Engagement and Evaluation
description:
The CIRES Center for Education, Engagement and Evaluation (CEEE) connects educators, learners, and communities with environmental and Earth system science. Our team provides accessible, high-quality environmental science curriculum and informal learning experiences, inclusive community building and engagement, meaningful career development, and research and evaluation support to evaluate the impact of education and science programs.

We strive to make science and research data accessible, inspire environmental action, and empower curiosity and scientific engagement for a sustainable future. We support future and early-career scientists through training and career opportunities. We collaborate with scientists to broaden the impact of their research through outreach activities and educational materials and to develop program evaluation plans for research proposals. We hold diversity, equity, inclusion, accessibility, and educational justice as core values in our work. 

CEEE (pronounced ‘C triple E’) has been serving educators, students, the science community, and the public since 1997 and was formerly known as CIRES Education & Outreach Program. Our team consists of scientists, data specialists, educators, evaluators, media experts, graphic designers, and outreach specialists.  

We believe the entire world benefits from science, but only if information and educational opportunities are shared with everyone. Connect with us and see where science can take you.

Students benefit from small classes; faculty dedicated to teaching and learning; a commitment to diversity and inclusiveness; and the beautiful, dynamic geography of Colorado and the Pikes Peak Region.
